rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 588px; height: 1px; padding-top: 65px; margin-left: 90px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Derivative:
It is a tool that tells us how fast something is changing at a single, exact moment.
A derivative is like knowing exactly how steep the slide is at one tiny spot.
- When you are at the very top, the slide is not steep yet, so the derivative is zero.
- When you go down the super steep part, the derivative is a big number because you are going very fast.
- When you get to the bottom where it's flat again, the derivative is zero.

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 588px; height: 1px; padding-top: 290px; margin-left: 90px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Gradient:
Gradient is the precise instruction for how to fix your mistake, and PyTorch is the tool that automatically creates those instructions for you.
Imagine you are a sculptor making a clay sculpture of a cat.
- Your Sculpture: It's a bunch of numbers in PyTorch that represent the shape of your cat.
- The Picture of a Real Cat: This is the correct answer you are trying to reach.
- Your Mistake: You compare your clay sculpture to the real cat picture and notice how far off you are. Maybe the ears are too flat, or the nose is too big. This "mistake" is called the loss.
- The Gradient: The gradient is like a special, magical sensor that tells you exactly how to push and pull every tiny bit of clay to make the sculpture look more like the real cat. It's a set of directions that points towards a smaller mistake.
- PyTorch's Magic: PyTorch has a magical engine called autograd. You don't have to figure out the directions yourself. You just do your sculpting (your calculations), and then you say .backward(), and the magical engine automatically figures out all the tiny, detailed adjustments you need to make to the clay.
- The Goal: You make a small adjustment to your sculpture based on PyTorch's directions, and then you check your mistake again. You repeat this process over and over, with each small adjustment making your sculpture look more and more like the real cat.

path.style: fill: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

rect.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 568px; height: 1px; padding-top: 545px; margin-left: 151px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Gradient descent is a way for a computer to get better at a game, kind of like a ball rolling down a hill to find the lowest spot.
Gradient descent helps computers learn by telling them, "Take a small step in the direction that makes your mistake smaller, until you make the tiniest mistake possible."
Imagine you are at the top of a big, grassy hill, and you want to find the very bottom where all the cool toys are. But you can't see the bottom because it's super foggy! So, what do you do?
1. Take a tiny step: You take one little step downhill.
2. Check: You see if that step made you go lower.
3. Keep going: You keep taking small steps in the steepest downhill direction until you can't go any lower.
4. Once you are at the bottom, you've found the best spot!
